question_text:
You have a Fabric workspace that contains an eventhouse and a KQL database named Database1. Database1 has the following:

A table named Table1 -

A table named Table2 -

An update policy named Policy1 -
Policy1 sends data from Table1 to Table2.
The following is a sample of the data in Table2.


Recently, the following actions were performed on Table1:
An additional element named temperature was added to the StreamData column.
The data type of the Timestamp column was changed to date.
The data type of the DeviceId column was changed to string.
You plan to load additional records to Table2.
Which two records will load from Table1 to Table2? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
discussion:
A and D have valid GUIds

Record B loads because it conforms to the updated schema (string DeviceId, StreamData with temperature).
Record D loads because it conforms to the original schema (guid DeviceId, no temperature in StreamData).

This is incorrect because it was only updated in Table 1. So passing a string to table2 which requires a GUID will fail when it is not a valid guid.

Even if Table 1 has device ID converted to String, Table 2 still expects the device ID to be in GUID. So only rows A and D meets that criteria.

Also when you insert a date into a datetime column, SQL will automatically convert the date to datetime by adding 00:00:00.000 as the time.

Can somebody please explain the answer? DeviceID is changes to string, so why does it need to have valid GUID-format? In mu opinion, the right answer should be A & B?

Changed my answer to A and D. I initially misinterpreted the question,  since the schema of Table2 has not been updated, only records A and D conform to the existing schema and will be successfully ingested

AD is correct!

Schema Requirements Recap:
Timestamp must be in date format.
DeviceId must be a string (GUID is acceptable).
StreamData must include the temperature field.
Record Analysis:
✅ Record A
Timestamp: ✅ Valid date (2024-05-18)
DeviceId: ✅ Valid GUID string
StreamData: ✅ Includes temperature
✅ Meets all criteria
❌ Record B
Timestamp: ✅ Valid date
DeviceId: ✅ String (though not a full GUID, still a string)
StreamData: ✅ Includes temperature
✅ Technically valid, though DeviceId is not a full GUID, it is a string — acceptable if schema only requires string

temperature

Please explain the answer

B and D. 
Because of GUID fields in the source data - The destination table schema has not been changed.
The third field with json data is probably of type nvarchar(max) which can accommodate any json structure.

I meant A and D. Answers with valid GUID

A & C have valid GUIds in correct format and also have temperature column

A & D have valid GUIds

Records B and C will not load because of invalid GUIDs
